MEDIA LOG II
Sir Arthur Eddington, in his New Pathways in Science
(Cambridge University Press 1935) makes a statement of rele¬
vance to those who are trying to understand why "the medium
is the message *w
"Out of the unknown activities of unknown agents mathe¬
matical numbers emerge. The processes of the external world
cannot be described in terms of familiar images; whether we
describe them by words or by symbols their intrinsic nature
remains unknown. But they are the vehicle of a scheme of
relationship which can be described by numbers, and so give
rise to those numerical measures (pointer-readings) which
are the data from which all knowledge of the external uni¬
verse is Inferred.
”Our account of the external world (when purged of the
Inventions of the story teller In consciousness) must neces¬
sarily be a Jabberwocky" of unknowable actors executing
unknowable actions. How In these conditions can we arrive
at any knowledge at all? We must seek a knowledge which is
neither of actors nor of actions, but of which the actors and
actions are a vehicle. The knowledge we can acquire is
knowledge of a structure or pattern contained In the actions.
